text:
I agree with <@UUXMCJQ15>! Growth marketers have KPIs aligned to acquiring new users from different channels and have very less to do with the post-acquisition part.

Whereas, product marketers work closely with Product teams to retain the existing ones by and work on re-activations emails, etc. They also work on giving insights from the market to the product team while building new features.

elements.text: I agree with

! Growth marketers have KPIs aligned to acquiring new users from different channels and have very less to do with the post-acquisition part.

Whereas, product marketers work closely with Product teams to retain the existing ones by and work on re-activations emails, etc. They also work on giving insights from the market to the product team while building new features.

text:
I think it's an important distinction. As <@UUXMCJQ15> said, there are plenty of small companies where someone will do both, but the lines between the work matter.

Growth marketing is very numbers oriented -- a good growth marketer will always be testing. optimizing, and exploring new channels. They work in spreadsheets, they spend a lot of time measuring things.

Product marketing is very narrative focused -- a good product marketing thinks deeply about how to position a product in the mind of potential buyers and communicate value. They work in stories and messaging frameworks, they spend a lot of time talking to customers.

A product marketer measured on growth metrics will be incredibly frustrated and also ineffective, and vice versa.

There is also an order in how this work should get done. Growth marketing should only be done after you have a solid product marketing foundation  in place -- strong positioning translated into clear messaging that resonates with your target audience. Doing growth marketing too soon means you spend a lot of time and money attracting bad fit leads (learned this lesson the hard way).

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

Product marketing is very narrative focused -- a good product marketing thinks deeply about how to position a product in the mind of potential buyers and communicate value. They work in stories and messaging frameworks, they spend a lot of time talking to customers.

A product marketer measured on growth metrics will be incredibly frustrated and also ineffective, and vice versa.

There is also an order in how this work should get done. Growth marketing should only be done after you have a solid product marketing foundation  in place -- strong positioning translated into clear messaging that resonates with your target audience. Doing growth marketing too soon means you spend a lot of time and money attracting bad fit leads (learned this lesson the hard way).

text:
We have five emails that trigger a few days apart after signing up for gated content. The opens go:
1 - 52%
2 - 30%
3 - 28%
4 - 26%
5 - 23%

text:
When it comes to content marketing, they're all over the place. I'm practically at the director level at most companies. At much larger companies (thousands of employees with an incomprehensible amount of departments), however, I'd be a senior manager.

If I could wave a wand and standardize the levels of seniority, I'd aim for something like:
• Content Marketing Writer
• Content Marketing Specialist / Editorial Assistant
• Content Marketing Manager
• Senior Content Marketing Manager
• Content (Marketing) Strategist
• Senior Content (Marketing) Strategist
• Director of Content Marketing and Strategy
• Senior Director of Content Marketing and Strategy
• VP of Content Marketing and Strategy
• and, I guess, Chief Content Marketing and Strategy Officer
The division between a content marketer and a content strategist, as it related to content marketing vs UX content strategy, is scope. A content marketer, in my mind, has one foot in the strategy and the other in execution. A content strategist has one foot in the strategy and the other in managing a team of content marketers.

I'd absolutely LOVE for someone to play Devil's Advocate or play "what-if" to my perspective, as well as add their own two cents (or tuppence).

text:
<@UUH2EB134> I’d love to hear more about the manager role coming before strategist. Our career pathing is similar except with those two reversed—but largely because “manager” is generally used for people management roles whereas “lead” would be our individual contributor equivalent. 

I’d also be curious where this group feels people management or being a team lead coincides with these roles.

elements.text:

text: The biggest challenge most of us deal with, whether internal or agency-side, is really building a fluid system between sales and marketing. The fix in many cases is (from my external experience) is making sure that attribution is working properly and tracking is set up to best help everybody do their job BEFORE focusing on traffic, conversions, MQLS, etc.
